Some dissatisfaction having been expressed A.
to the manner in which the recent meeting held
OF these subjects was conducted, as well as at
the result thereof, and several of the Delegates
appointed at said meeting having declined to
act under their appointment-the citizens of the
State Of Delaware, friendly to the protection Of
American labor, and to the encouragement Of
home market, are invited to meet again At the
Town Hall in Wilmington, on Saturday the 2lst
inst. at 3 O'Clock.


With view that the proposed meeting should
stand on the face and pure ground Of the great
National Interests in question, it is hereby de-
cared, that the object Of the present call, is to
promote the interest Of Agriculture and Manu-
factures, by expressing our sentiments publicly
on those important subjects, and to appoint Del
Harrisburg on the 30th inst.

PUBLIC MEETING


OF THE FRIENDS OF
A griculture and Manufactures.

ave call back. maid of Lutha, years that have


rolled away" OsslAH.
Yes, l remember her; saw her first
In the sweet prime Of fwomanh0od-thc rose
Ofhealth, in young and dcwy freshness, bloom.
Upon her cheek; and from her dark blue eye
The spirit of each newborn thought looked out
In undsguised expression, and dillussd
Over her face its own pure loneliness!
Oh, she was one of those for whom the earth


seemed


Even in summer rbcauty-hinty brows
Melted to smiles, and hearts unwont to feel
Softcncd to tenderness -Where'er she moved
Each eye looked gladness, and each voice
In its best tones spoke welcome; and the world
Was proud other. Yet she, SO loved, caressed,
And followed, was all mcekness-her whole
A deep pure fount of ofblessing-such she was


A change came o'er: the fell, blasting breath
of SANDER; like the siroc, passed. Ere yet
The sun had kissed away its dew, we saw
The lovelest flower morn ever smiled on droop.


Sorrow was wasting fast the springs of life.
She was alone-pale, pale, but lovely still.
Friends who had looked but to her slightest


smile


For happiness, had long forsakcn her!
1t was summers eve-the sun had sunk
Down from golden sky, whence brightly


streamed


Far over wood and field saffron light,
That rested, like lovely dream, on all
The gilded landscape: the sweet breath Of flow


ers


Came on the silent air, stealing the soul
Like angel harpings heard in Eden's bower,
Or airs of Heaven commissioned oft to soothe
The mortal anguish of the dying saint!


She looked with mild sadness on the scene
Fading like her-"And had hoped," she said,
envy evening sun would set in its full time
Like this!" Oh world, thy visitngs OF scorn
Are fearful to the young and innocent heart.
She sank beneath theIn--and the plying earth,
Whose gentle bosom never spurned child
Of sorrow, nor received lovelier guest,
Hath dccked her grave with freshest green and


flowers.

Thc annulment Of the marriage Of Z. G. Wake
field to Miss Turner was before the House OF
Lords on the goth. Miss Turner was examined,
and gave her evidence in q distinct and unem-
barrassed manner Other witnesses were exam
ined, when Mr.. Wakefield addressed the House
and requested a postponement OH the ground
that he was not prepared, which was not grant
ed, and the evidence was ordered to be printed,
and the bill was committed for the next day.

Commeni3rotiou by the .hfrioans.-ln ac-
cordance with the feelings expressed by the


meeting of respectable coloured people, the
proceedings of which we're published IN this
paper, the 4th OF July, the day when slave
ry ceased forever in this state, was celebrat-
ed by the class of inhabitants interested IN
that event in an appropriate and highly be-
coming manner.


Lon Church, at the corner of Church and
Leonard streets. was opened, and an Grafton
delivered by Mr.. William Hamilton, before
the different societies Of colorcd persons.--
The church was ornarcnted with por-
trait Of Matthew Clarkson one of John Jay,
a portrait and a bust OF Daniel d. Ionipkins,
and bust Of President Boyer. Many small
banners and flags were also displayed. Sew
eral hymns, written for the occasion, were
sung.


On the 5th the various societies, viz the
Mutual Relief, the Wilbeiorcc, Clarkson,
Union, Brooklyn. &c. and large body Of
coored people from Brooklyn, and other
towns in this state, to the number of between
and 40e0 formed a line in Hudson square,
and marched through the principal streets,
under their respective banners. with music,
and directed by a marshal on horseback, to
ZION Church; where an Grafton WAS deliyei- :
ed by Mr.. John Mitchell. The church was
decorated with banners as the day before
The audience were remarkably well dress
ed, and conducted themselves in the pro-
cession with great propriety.

The New Hampshire Medical Society
have adopted series of resolves relative
to the use of Spirituous Liquors, similar to
those lately adopted by the Massachusetts,
society. They say that the use of distilled
spirit is nepe1 necessary in the treatment of
single disease.

atoga Springs; the chief having resorted
there tor the recovery of his health. They
have their tents, and encamp on piece OF
ground short distance south OF the village.

SCRAPS.

IN commencing work of so much i'm
portance to the citizens of this Borough, as
that of introducing the water from the Bran
dywine. you will doubtless appreciate every
hint that may tend to the most advantage
GUS application of philosophical principles,
SO as to derive from limited power, the
most useful results of which it is susceptible.


have been told that you propose drawing
the water for the use of the borough from
the tail-race, as it is called. or after it has
passed the water-whccl, instead of taking it
from its original elevation.


Now this will render the apparatus more
complicated and expensive, at the same time
it will furnish much less quantity of water
to the reservoir; consequently injurc the
mill by requiring too long time to work the
pumps.


II is said that MIR. Graft recommends this
plan. We are too well acquainted with the
practical talents of that gentleman to believe
for a moment, he would ever recommend
such a measure. if he was possessed of all
the circumstances attendant ON the under
taking Nothing but the most imperious me-
cessity, we are persuaded, could induce him
to propose such peryerson of mechanical
power. But here no such necessity exists
We are entitled by the purchase to all the
water that can flow through a certain ap
erture. say los inches, and every person the
least acquainted with mechanics and the
pressure Of fluids, knows very we'll that it
will require at least three gallons on the
wheel, in order to raise two gallons to an e.
quail elevation. Why then incur an addi-
tional expcnce to render the pump more
complicated. for purpose worse than use
less! Why not conduct the water from the
gate directly at the pump and thereby re-
tain an additional power equal at least to
one half of the quantity used by the citizens.

For the Uilmingioa,an.
THE WATER WORKS.
To THE WATERING CoMMIrTEg.

Mr.. Wurts, ofPcnnsylvania, Of said he had
understood the object of the bill was to en-
force the due execution Of our revenue laws.


Mr.. Dwight, whose acquaintance with the
subject will scarcely be called in question,
used the following language:


"An inquiry has been made whether the
bill went further than to carry into effect
the provisions OF the law of 1924. 1t has al
ready been stated that such is the object of
the bill. it is to make the duty calculated
equal 10 SO 1-3 hcr cent. on all goods. If it
could be shown that. although the law of
1924 imposed duty of SO l.3 there was only
Is per cent collected, it would be evident
that there was AN evasion OF the law. We
ought to ask no more than the efficient ope-
ration of that law. The manufacturers ask
no more"


Mr.. Pcarce, of Rhode Island, having a
practical knowledge ofth subject, said,


at has been my purpose to show that the
provisions of this bill only secure to the man.
ufacturer of wool what, upon fair valua-
ton, he had right to expect from the act
of 1924"


1t will be seen then. from these extracts,



lens Bills in harmony with the opinions aud

sion. We find further confederation in

men who addressed the recent meeting of

| ton.

"Our tariff of duties was revised in 1924,
aud it was to be expected that Congress

what they intended by that revision"


Mr.. z. Everett, in reference to the law Of

THAT law had wholly failed of its design.
ed effect in favor of the wolllen manufac
ture. This failure came in one of two ways
either the law was inadequate, or it hat

We make the following additional quota
ton from Mr.. Evcrctt's remarks for tn,

nature Of the notifications made Ly til,
British Parliament, which operated to de

The operation OF the reduction of the du
ty on the raW materia! i'll Great Britain
was in truth an cifSct to reduce the dut,
OF 35 is per cent. laid by Congress on til,
importation of British woollcns, to IS 2-3 pi
cent. Nor was this all-Pai Lament ais,
reduced the dutes on olive oil, raprseet
and indigo about e-half which was in IF
feet, further reduction of the duty o'
woolens imported into the United States
Of per cent. The result was that the pro
tectiug duty Of So 1-3 per cent. laid by tn,
American Congress for the encouragement
of woollcn manufactures, had been reduce,
by the Acts of the British Parliament Il
10 2-3 per cent; and he would ask. wheth
er this was not the same in effect as il tn
Congress of the United States had repealed
the tariff of duties as far as regards thi
branch of industry, and established dut,
of 16 1-3 per cent. What the British manu-
facturer lost in the duty here he gained il
the smaller price Of the raw materials a
home; the British Parliament defeated TIL
: law by laying burden upon their farmer
: by taking off the duty on wool impoi ted
, We think we have thus satisfactorily res
q cued ourselves from the charge OF attempt
ing to deludc the public by sophistry Be
yond that, we are of opinion that we hav
t shown our views to be coincidcnt with thos
of the best information OH the subject, an,
to be such as reason seems to dictate, am
experience to approve.

letter from Vera Cruz OF the 22d of

"Commodore Porter has arrived from

"Thc government has complimented

isied with his conduct.


Bear Fight-Mr. Andrew c. Bigelow
and Mr.. Harvey Bliss, of Tlcondcrosa
while engaged in fishing in small canoe
d few weeks since, on Long pond, discover.
ed huge bear playing in the river ncai
them. Being armed enly with towing
piece loaded with shot, they discharged u
into his face, which so enraged the mon
ster. that he SWAIN tOWdIQ tnCW Will iul
speed apparently determined on revenge
for being thus insulted while quietly bath.
ing tor his own sport or amusement. The
bear made repeated attempts to overturr
the canoe, but the men not having time L
reload their piece. as often piled the paddles
upon his pate, until they succeeded IN con
quering him. He was dragged ashore ant
found to weigh 500 pounds.

AyreS OF 24th March.


IMPERIAL BARBARISM.


A respectable literary gentleman, recent
ly arrived at Montcviteo, has communcat-
ed to friend in this place relation (Which
he had from the principal physician of the
deceased Empress OF Brazil) OF the event
which occasioned the illness and death OF
that unfortunate lady.


According to this account, tie Empress
had purchased two horses which had struck
her with admiration BY their elegance and
beauty. The chief Major Domo of the En-
pcror, who supplied her Majesty with what
was necessary for her cxpcnces, either to
fiatter his master, or from some other mo.
tive. intmated to him that the Empress ex-
pended a considerable deal Of money; as, fer
the last five or six months. the sums she had
asked exceeded, already, seven thousand
dollars.' The Etnperor desired to see the
account, and observed that the price Of the
two horses was not included, FOR the pay
ment of which the Major Domo said he had
not funds. In consequence, Don Pedro pre-
sented himself before her Majesty, with
whom he commenced disputing, calling her,
to her face, an extravagant spcndthrift, &c.
1t seems that the Empress answered, that
when she was mere princess, she had
much greater sum assigned for her purse
than that which was now allowed her. The
conversation fell upon the horses, when the
Emperor rcproached her with unnecessary
expense, where she had, already, horses
sufficient. The Empress observed that they
had pleased her very much on account OF
their singular beauty, and that it his maJes-
ty did not wish to pay for them. as he in
sinuated. she would do SO. though it should
be by selling one of her jewels. The En-
peror replied that he would dispose Of them.
as he wished to present them to the little
Marquesite daughter of the Marchiones ss
of Santos. The Empress stung with indig-
nation, (as she well might be, at the propos-
cd mode of adjusting the matter,) made an
! swcr that she would sooner have their
threats cut. than permit that SO 79orthtcss an
Individual should display her horses. The
Emperor, then infuriated, struck her majes-
ty violent blow on her face, that knocked
her to the foor and, while III that situation,
kicked her several tines! Leaving her ex-
tremely i'll in consequence of this usage, he
came to Rio Grande: and lastly, it is stated
that her majesty being examined after her
death, the fetus which she had then in the
womb, was found with the head mutilated,
and, already, even in state OF putrefac-
tion!i


.Surely this is a sum rather exiguous for per-
sonage of such class-the more so in the case OF
her maiesty, whose charity was SO notorious, and
who extended her benevoience to all the unhap-
py who implored it.


As there is at this time an opinion existing
in our Borough. rather unfavourable to the
encouragement Of woollen protection, the
following compilation of opinions upon he
subject, from the National Journal may serve
to throw some new light upon the subject :


Mr.. Davis, Of Massachusetts,. whose speech
on the woollens bill was considered by men
of all parties as one of extraordinary strength
and pertinence, who was of the Committee
which prepared the bill, and who had made
himself perfectly acquainted with the ope'
ration of the law of 1924, says


"The law OF 1924 gave duty OF So Is
per centum on imported fabrics; and it was
doubtless the design of the government that
it should operate as clear protective duty;
but one half lit, or nearly that amount,
has been taken away by the Modification OF
the British Tariff, and the other halt is evad,


ed. The memoralists, therefore, demand
no more than what is reasonable, when they
seek to obtain the full advantages in1ehoeo
IMrERIAL BARBARISM.

We have received by an arrival at Boston
from Buenos Ayres, files of the "Argcntinc
News" and "American" to the 3lst March,
from which we have extracted such items
of intelligence as afford the most interest.
The difficulties existing between the dissi-
dent provinces and the General Government
have not yet been adjusted-neither is it
expected they shortly will The effect OF
force. on the part Of the Government, in en-
deavoring to bring these provinces to sub
lection, has been to widen instead of closing
the breach In preceding column. under
the Buenos Ayres head. will be found a
sketch Of the state and condition of each
province; to which we refer the reader for
more general intor nation.

among the crews of the vessels composing
lis squadron.

full articles.headline:
PUBLIC MEETING


OF THE FRIENDS OF
A griculture and Manufactures.
full articles.article:
Some dissatisfaction having been expressed A.
to the manner in which the recent meeting held
OF these subjects was conducted, as well as at
the result thereof, and several of the Delegates
appointed at said meeting having declined to
act under their appointment-the citizens of the
State Of Delaware, friendly to the protection Of
American labor, and to the encouragement Of
home market, are invited to meet again At the
Town Hall in Wilmington, on Saturday the 2lst
inst. at 3 O'Clock.


With view that the proposed meeting should
stand on the face and pure ground Of the great
National Interests in question, it is hereby de-
cared, that the object Of the present call, is to
promote the interest Of Agriculture and Manu-
factures, by expressing our sentiments publicly
on those important subjects, and to appoint Del
Harrisburg on the 30th inst.

ave call back. maid of Lutha, years that have


rolled away" OsslAH.
Yes, l remember her; saw her first
In the sweet prime Of fwomanh0od-thc rose
Ofhealth, in young and dcwy freshness, bloom.
Upon her cheek; and from her dark blue eye
The spirit of each newborn thought looked out
In undsguised expression, and dillussd
Over her face its own pure loneliness!
Oh, she was one of those for whom the earth


seemed


Even in summer rbcauty-hinty brows
Melted to smiles, and hearts unwont to feel
Softcncd to tenderness -Where'er she moved
Each eye looked gladness, and each voice
In its best tones spoke welcome; and the world
Was proud other. Yet she, SO loved, caressed,
And followed, was all mcekness-her whole
A deep pure fount of ofblessing-such she was


A change came o'er: the fell, blasting breath
of SANDER; like the siroc, passed. Ere yet
The sun had kissed away its dew, we saw
The lovelest flower morn ever smiled on droop.


Sorrow was wasting fast the springs of life.
She was alone-pale, pale, but lovely still.
Friends who had looked but to her slightest


smile


For happiness, had long forsakcn her!
1t was summers eve-the sun had sunk
Down from golden sky, whence brightly


streamed


Far over wood and field saffron light,
That rested, like lovely dream, on all
The gilded landscape: the sweet breath Of flow


ers


Came on the silent air, stealing the soul
Like angel harpings heard in Eden's bower,
Or airs of Heaven commissioned oft to soothe
The mortal anguish of the dying saint!


She looked with mild sadness on the scene
Fading like her-"And had hoped," she said,
envy evening sun would set in its full time
Like this!" Oh world, thy visitngs OF scorn
Are fearful to the young and innocent heart.
She sank beneath theIn--and the plying earth,
Whose gentle bosom never spurned child
Of sorrow, nor received lovelier guest,
Hath dccked her grave with freshest green and


flowers.

full articles.headline:
FOREIGN INTELLIdENCE.

FROM ENGLAND.
full articles.article:
The ship Chill, Captain jenkins, 81 days from
Liverpool, and the ship Friends, Capt. Warnack,

Public confidence was increasing IN the new
administration, and the funds have advanced in
consequence.


Ii was rumoured that the King of England had
written to the Duke Of Wellington, requesting
him to resume the command the army, which
lie had declined.


A speedy and powerful intervention in favor Of
the Greeks was about to take place-so say the
French papers.


Thc annulment Of the marriage Of Z. G. Wake
field to Miss Turner was before the House OF
Lords on the goth. Miss Turner was examined,
and gave her evidence in q distinct and unem-
barrassed manner Other witnesses were exam
ined, when Mr.. Wakefield addressed the House
and requested a postponement OH the ground
that he was not prepared, which was not grant
ed, and the evidence was ordered to be printed,
and the bill was committed for the next day.


Great sensation was produced in London on
the 26th in consequence of intelligence from N.
York, of the misunderstanding between the Bra
lillian and United States Governments, and that
Mr.. Racquet had demanded his passports


Constantnople dates say that the Divan had
commenced carrying into execution the prnci'
pal articles of the treaty Of Ackcrman, aud that
the best understanding prevailed between the
Porte and the Russian legation.

dated Madrid, May l4th, states the Spanish Gen
erals complain much Of desertons from Their
armies, and to be anxious to retire from the Por
tuguese frontier, unless they are permitted t.
cross it.


| A letter from Liverpool Of May 29th, says


Yesterday, about 1000 bags of Cotton were sole
at the lowest rates of last week The average
qualities of Uplands and Alabamas are now near
| ly unsaleable at Gid per pound.


"rhe motion for going into committee "poI
the CORN BILL in the House o! Loid5, ha
been carried by l20 votes to 90.

full articles.headline: From, the AZ Y. Duily advertiser.
full articles.article:
Commeni3rotiou by the .hfrioans.-ln ac-
cordance with the feelings expressed by the


meeting of respectable coloured people, the
proceedings of which we're published IN this
paper, the 4th OF July, the day when slave
ry ceased forever in this state, was celebrat-
ed by the class of inhabitants interested IN
that event in an appropriate and highly be-
coming manner.


Lon Church, at the corner of Church and
Leonard streets. was opened, and an Grafton
delivered by Mr.. William Hamilton, before
the different societies Of colorcd persons.--
The church was ornarcnted with por-
trait Of Matthew Clarkson one of John Jay,
a portrait and a bust OF Daniel d. Ionipkins,
and bust Of President Boyer. Many small
banners and flags were also displayed. Sew
eral hymns, written for the occasion, were
sung.


On the 5th the various societies, viz the
Mutual Relief, the Wilbeiorcc, Clarkson,
Union, Brooklyn. &c. and large body Of
coored people from Brooklyn, and other
towns in this state, to the number of between
and 40e0 formed a line in Hudson square,
and marched through the principal streets,
under their respective banners. with music,
and directed by a marshal on horseback, to
ZION Church; where an Grafton WAS deliyei- :
ed by Mr.. John Mitchell. The church was
decorated with banners as the day before
The audience were remarkably well dress
ed, and conducted themselves in the pro-
cession with great propriety.

full articles.article:
Mr.. Lieber, celebrated teacher OF gym
nastics in London, has accepted an invitation
to superintcnd the Boston Gymnasium, and
has arrived at New-York.


William B. Rochester, Esq. Secretary to
the Mission of Mexico which place he left
the 11th of May, arrived at Louisville, Ken
lucky, on the 18th of June, OH his return
home.


The New Hampshire Medical Society
have adopted series of resolves relative
to the use of Spirituous Liquors, similar to
those lately adopted by the Massachusetts,
society. They say that the use of distilled
spirit is nepe1 necessary in the treatment of
single disease.


The chief of the Oneida Indians, with 8
or 10 OF his own nation. are now at the Sar-
atoga Springs; the chief having resorted
there tor the recovery of his health. They
have their tents, and encamp on piece OF
ground short distance south OF the village.

OF whom died before the vessel reached ST.
ezra Leone! The same vessel carried off

ssaid, that the slaye trade is nearly d6oi-
she'd

The whole number the present season is
1852, none of whom have come under gov
eminent patronage.

lures tor the support of the prison, by the
sum of S3.2f1. The sales Of hammered

The New-York American states that the
wonderful dog Apollo, exhibiting at the A.
Merlcan Mus seum-and whose performanc-
Is are almost incredible--was sold few
Gays since, for the sum Of eight hundred
dollars.

,n'aety years; the costliest that ever was,
SO'h tor time. blood and money. No con-
nc' IS SO fierce as when religion anmates
w, We war, and makes it piety to be irreconcil-
able

Wfort Delaware, were drowned by the cap

full articles.headline:
For the Uilmingioa,an.
THE WATER WORKS.
full articles.article:
IN commencing work of so much i'm
portance to the citizens of this Borough, as
that of introducing the water from the Bran
dywine. you will doubtless appreciate every
hint that may tend to the most advantage
GUS application of philosophical principles,
SO as to derive from limited power, the
most useful results of which it is susceptible.


have been told that you propose drawing
the water for the use of the borough from
the tail-race, as it is called. or after it has
passed the water-whccl, instead of taking it
from its original elevation.


Now this will render the apparatus more
complicated and expensive, at the same time
it will furnish much less quantity of water
to the reservoir; consequently injurc the
mill by requiring too long time to work the
pumps.


II is said that MIR. Graft recommends this
plan. We are too well acquainted with the
practical talents of that gentleman to believe
for a moment, he would ever recommend
such a measure. if he was possessed of all
the circumstances attendant ON the under
taking Nothing but the most imperious me-
cessity, we are persuaded, could induce him
to propose such peryerson of mechanical
power. But here no such necessity exists
We are entitled by the purchase to all the
water that can flow through a certain ap
erture. say los inches, and every person the
least acquainted with mechanics and the
pressure Of fluids, knows very we'll that it
will require at least three gallons on the
wheel, in order to raise two gallons to an e.
quail elevation. Why then incur an addi-
tional expcnce to render the pump more
complicated. for purpose worse than use
less! Why not conduct the water from the
gate directly at the pump and thereby re-
tain an additional power equal at least to
one half of the quantity used by the citizens.

full articles.headline: MARRIED.
full articles.article:
On Sunday afternoon, the 9Th inst in New
Ark, by the Rev A. X. Russell, Mr., SAMUEL
SIMPSON ofPladelphia, to Miss HAsSAH MARIA,
eldest daughter Of Peter ogle Esq. Of chris,iaha
Del.


Oh she was every way tivinely fair,


Charming in person, and in soul sincere;


She was, alas! more than muse can tell,


Well worthy love, and was beloved as well.

DTitISn mOQlHCdtlOn, ana tHc character OF
the frauds by which the provisions Of the
law Of 1924 are evaded.


Mr.. Wurts, ofPcnnsylvania, Of said he had
understood the object of the bill was to en-
force the due execution Of our revenue laws.


Mr.. Dwight, whose acquaintance with the
subject will scarcely be called in question,
used the following language:


"An inquiry has been made whether the
bill went further than to carry into effect
the provisions OF the law of 1924. 1t has al
ready been stated that such is the object of
the bill. it is to make the duty calculated
equal 10 SO 1-3 hcr cent. on all goods. If it
could be shown that. although the law of
1924 imposed duty of SO l.3 there was only
Is per cent collected, it would be evident
that there was AN evasion OF the law. We
ought to ask no more than the efficient ope-
ration of that law. The manufacturers ask
no more"


Mr.. Pcarce, of Rhode Island, having a
practical knowledge ofth subject, said,


at has been my purpose to show that the
provisions of this bill only secure to the man.
ufacturer of wool what, upon fair valua-
ton, he had right to expect from the act
of 1924"


1t will be seen then. from these extracts,



lens Bills in harmony with the opinions aud
statements OF some Of the prominent mem
bers who spoke ON the subject al the last ses-
sion. We find further confederation in
the remarks offered by some of the gentle
men who addressed the recent meeting of
growers and manufacturers of wool at Bos-
| ton.


Mr.. Abbot Laurence is reported to have
thus expressed himself


"Our tariff of duties was revised in 1924,
aud it was to be expected that Congress
would do for the woulen manufacturers
what they intended by that revision"


Mr.. z. Everett, in reference to the law Of
1924, is stated to have said


THAT law had wholly failed of its design.
ed effect in favor of the wolllen manufac
ture. This failure came in one of two ways
either the law was inadequate, or it hat
been defeated. The latter was the fact. 'rh,
! provisions Of the law OF 1894. so far as re
garded the encouragement of weollcn manu-
tacturcs. had been uotoriously and ruinousl
defeated"


We make the following additional quota
ton from Mr.. Evcrctt's remarks for tn,
purpose Of placing before cur readers th'
nature Of the notifications made Ly til,
British Parliament, which operated to de
feat the provisions Of the law Of 1894.


The operation OF the reduction of the du
ty on the raW materia! i'll Great Britain
was in truth an cifSct to reduce the dut,
OF 35 is per cent. laid by Congress on til,
importation of British woollcns, to IS 2-3 pi
cent. Nor was this all-Pai Lament ais,
reduced the dutes on olive oil, raprseet
and indigo about e-half which was in IF
feet, further reduction of the duty o'
woolens imported into the United States
Of per cent. The result was that the pro
tectiug duty Of So 1-3 per cent. laid by tn,
American Congress for the encouragement
of woollcn manufactures, had been reduce,
by the Acts of the British Parliament Il
10 2-3 per cent; and he would ask. wheth
er this was not the same in effect as il tn
Congress of the United States had repealed
the tariff of duties as far as regards thi
branch of industry, and established dut,
of 16 1-3 per cent. What the British manu-
facturer lost in the duty here he gained il
the smaller price Of the raw materials a
home; the British Parliament defeated TIL
: law by laying burden upon their farmer
: by taking off the duty on wool impoi ted
, We think we have thus satisfactorily res
q cued ourselves from the charge OF attempt
ing to deludc the public by sophistry Be
yond that, we are of opinion that we hav
t shown our views to be coincidcnt with thos
of the best information OH the subject, an,
to be such as reason seems to dictate, am
experience to approve.

tended by the Foreign Consuls, the North A.
merican and Chilian officers, the Governor Of
the Province, and many persons Of distinction.

full articles.headline:
DRAWING OF The
Delaware State Lottery.
full articles.article:
For the benefit of Newark College, Middletown


Academy and Emmanuel Church.


SEVENTH CLASS.


The subscribers being requested to superin-
tend the drawing of the DELAWARE STATE
LOTTERY, Seventh Class, do hereby certify
that the following are the numbers that were this
day drawn from the si1ty numbers placed in the
wheel, viz:


43. 4. 38. ~. 20. 81. 40. 5.
And that the said numbers were drawn in the or
er in which they stand above; that is to say. No.
43 was the first, No. was the second, No. 38
was the third, No. Al was the fourth, No. 20 Twas
the fifth, No. 54 W the sixtn, No. 40 was the
seventh, and No. S was the eighth and last.


Witness our hands, at Wilmington, this 9th


day of July, 1897.
FREDERICK LEONARD,
JOHN M'CLUNG.


SAMUEL HARKER.

letter from Vera Cruz OF the 22d of
May states,


"Commodore Porter has arrived from
Kew West very unexpectedly, but oppor-
,n,ly. as the officers in Vera Cruz threw
every obstacle in the way to prevent the
spplies from sailing. which the Commo-
lorc had been expecting for long tune
Two or three fellows have command OF the
ycssels-they are the most notorious cow
ards in christendom, and by making thou
sand excuses and apologies, thcy oeiay-
ed so long that Com. Porter lett his rrlgate
in Kew West, the Bravo, out on cruze, and
came here in small sloop--hc was mere
but a short time, only one day, when ne mad
the vessels ready for sea; this was done IKE
magic He has made complete revolution
in affairs--he arrested Capt Machln OF the
brig Victoria, | suspect for cowardice CT dis
obedience of orders, caused by tears which
nlachin entertained for a Privateer, which
is cruising off Campcachy, and has made
six or seyen captures.


"Thc government has complimented
Com. Porter very highly. and is we'll sat
isied with his conduct.


Bear Fight-Mr. Andrew c. Bigelow
and Mr.. Harvey Bliss, of Tlcondcrosa
while engaged in fishing in small canoe
d few weeks since, on Long pond, discover.
ed huge bear playing in the river ncai
them. Being armed enly with towing
piece loaded with shot, they discharged u
into his face, which so enraged the mon
ster. that he SWAIN tOWdIQ tnCW Will iul
speed apparently determined on revenge
for being thus insulted while quietly bath.
ing tor his own sport or amusement. The
bear made repeated attempts to overturr
the canoe, but the men not having time L
reload their piece. as often piled the paddles
upon his pate, until they succeeded IN con
quering him. He was dragged ashore ant
found to weigh 500 pounds.


During the storm at Philadelphia on til,
4th int several accidents occurred. A boa
capsized near the Navy Yard, and of iiv
boys that were on board, three were down
ed Another boat in which were two youn
men, was upset; they saved themselves b
getting ON the keel. A sloop at Smith
Island was struck by lightning, two me
knocked down, two others severely shock
ed, and dog killed in the hold tree op
postc tavern beyond the permanent bridg
was struck. and man who was in the hous
Knocked down. 1t is also said, that sta


bic on the Schuylkill was struck, and COY
killed.

full articles.headline: IMrERIAL BARBARISM.
full articles.article:
AyreS OF 24th March.


IMPERIAL BARBARISM.


A respectable literary gentleman, recent
ly arrived at Montcviteo, has communcat-
ed to friend in this place relation (Which
he had from the principal physician of the
deceased Empress OF Brazil) OF the event
which occasioned the illness and death OF
that unfortunate lady.


According to this account, tie Empress
had purchased two horses which had struck
her with admiration BY their elegance and
beauty. The chief Major Domo of the En-
pcror, who supplied her Majesty with what
was necessary for her cxpcnces, either to
fiatter his master, or from some other mo.
tive. intmated to him that the Empress ex-
pended a considerable deal Of money; as, fer
the last five or six months. the sums she had
asked exceeded, already, seven thousand
dollars.' The Etnperor desired to see the
account, and observed that the price Of the
two horses was not included, FOR the pay
ment of which the Major Domo said he had
not funds. In consequence, Don Pedro pre-
sented himself before her Majesty, with
whom he commenced disputing, calling her,
to her face, an extravagant spcndthrift, &c.
1t seems that the Empress answered, that
when she was mere princess, she had
much greater sum assigned for her purse
than that which was now allowed her. The
conversation fell upon the horses, when the
Emperor rcproached her with unnecessary
expense, where she had, already, horses
sufficient. The Empress observed that they
had pleased her very much on account OF
their singular beauty, and that it his maJes-
ty did not wish to pay for them. as he in
sinuated. she would do SO. though it should
be by selling one of her jewels. The En-
peror replied that he would dispose Of them.
as he wished to present them to the little
Marquesite daughter of the Marchiones ss
of Santos. The Empress stung with indig-
nation, (as she well might be, at the propos-
cd mode of adjusting the matter,) made an
! swcr that she would sooner have their
threats cut. than permit that SO 79orthtcss an
Individual should display her horses. The
Emperor, then infuriated, struck her majes-
ty violent blow on her face, that knocked
her to the foor and, while III that situation,
kicked her several tines! Leaving her ex-
tremely i'll in consequence of this usage, he
came to Rio Grande: and lastly, it is stated
that her majesty being examined after her
death, the fetus which she had then in the
womb, was found with the head mutilated,
and, already, even in state OF putrefac-
tion!i


.Surely this is a sum rather exiguous for per-
sonage of such class-the more so in the case OF
her maiesty, whose charity was SO notorious, and
who extended her benevoience to all the unhap-
py who implored it.


As there is at this time an opinion existing
in our Borough. rather unfavourable to the
encouragement Of woollen protection, the
following compilation of opinions upon he
subject, from the National Journal may serve
to throw some new light upon the subject :


Mr.. Davis, Of Massachusetts,. whose speech
on the woollens bill was considered by men
of all parties as one of extraordinary strength
and pertinence, who was of the Committee
which prepared the bill, and who had made
himself perfectly acquainted with the ope'
ration of the law of 1924, says


"The law OF 1924 gave duty OF So Is
per centum on imported fabrics; and it was
doubtless the design of the government that
it should operate as clear protective duty;
but one half lit, or nearly that amount,
has been taken away by the Modification OF
the British Tariff, and the other halt is evad,


ed. The memoralists, therefore, demand
no more than what is reasonable, when they
seek to obtain the full advantages in1ehoeo

We have received by an arrival at Boston
from Buenos Ayres, files of the "Argcntinc
News" and "American" to the 3lst March,
from which we have extracted such items
of intelligence as afford the most interest.
The difficulties existing between the dissi-
dent provinces and the General Government
have not yet been adjusted-neither is it
expected they shortly will The effect OF
force. on the part Of the Government, in en-
deavoring to bring these provinces to sub
lection, has been to widen instead of closing
the breach In preceding column. under
the Buenos Ayres head. will be found a
sketch Of the state and condition of each
province; to which we refer the reader for
more general intor nation.


The worth Of the Brazilian vessels taken
on the Uruguay, by Admiral Brown, is esti-
mated at 5000, ,0c0; which is to be distributed
among the crews of the vessels composing
lis squadron.
